bibl.title: Military Orders for John W. Ross, February 6, 1901 [selected page]

div1.p: Special Orders #31, Headquarters of the Army, assigns Ross to duty in Havana. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Military Orders for John W. Ross, February 6, 1901 [selected page]
div1.p:
FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Spec Orders
Vol 1 - 1901

HEADQUARTERS OF THE ARMY,
ADJUTANT GENERAL'S OFFICE,
Washington, February 6, 1901.

1. By direction of the Secretary of War, Surgeon John W.
Ross, U. S. Navy, retired, having been assigned to duty under
the War Department, will proceed to Havana, Cuba, and re-
port in person to the commanding general, Department of
Cuba, for assignment to duty. The travel enjoined is neces-
sary for the public service.

2. By direction of the Secretary of War, Captains John T.
French, jr., and Carroll A. Devol, assistant quartermasters,
U. S. Army, will report in person to Lieutenant Colonel Henry
G. Sharpe, assistant commissary general of subsistence, U. S.
Army, president of the examining board appointed by Special
Orders, No. 269, November 15, 1900, from this office, to meet at
the War Department, in this city, at such time as he may desig-
nate, for examination as to their fitness for promotion, and
upon the completion thereof will return to their proper sta-
tions. The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

3. By direction of the Secretary of War, Sergeant Irving
Houghton, Company C, 10th Infantry, now on furlough in this
city, is transferred as private to the general recruiting service,
infantry. He will report on or before expiration of his fur-
lough to the commanding officer, Fort Columbus, New York,
who will furnish him transportation to Springfield, Massachu-
setts. Upon his arrival there he will report to the officer in
charge of the recruiting station, Cooley Place, for duty.

4. By direction of the Secretary of War, Post Quartermaster
Sergeant Benjamin A. Yates, now at the Presidio of San Fran-
cisco, California, is relieved from further duty in the Division
of the Philippines. He will be sent to Fort Baker, California,
and will report upon arrival to the commanding officer of that
post for duty.

5. By direction of the Secretary of War, Corporal Albert H.
Mansky, Company L, 23d Infantry, now in the hands of the
civil authorities serving sentence of imprisonment, will be
discharged without honor from the Army by the commanding
officer, Fort Douglas, Utah. This soldier is not entitled to
travel-pay.
